[[File:Flybrid Systems Kinetic Energy Recovery System.jpg|thumb|right|A Flybrid Systems kinetic energy recovery system.]] A '''kinetic energy recovery system''' (often known simply as '''KERS)''' is an automotive system for [[energy recovery|recovering]] a moving [[vehicle]]'s [[kinetic energy]] [[Regenerative brake|under braking]]. The recovered energy is stored in a reservoir (for example a [[flywheel]] or high voltage batteries) for later use under acceleration. Examples include complex high end systems such as the [[Zytek]], Flybrid,<ref>{{cite web|author=Flybrid Systems LLP |url=http://www.flybridsystems.com/Technology.html |title=Flybrid Systems |publisher=Flybrid Systems |date=2010-09-10 |accessdate=2010-09-17}}</ref> Torotrak<ref>[http://www.torotrak.com/IVT/works/ Torotrak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100629021239/http://www.torotrak.com/IVT/works/ |date=June 29, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xtrac.com/pdfs/Torotrak_Xtrac_CVT.pdf |title=Torotrak, Xtrac & CVT pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-09-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303112839/http://www.xtrac.com/pdfs/Torotrak_Xtrac_CVT.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-03 |df= }}</ref> and Xtrac used in [[Formula One racing]] and simple, easily manufactured and integrated [[Differential (mechanical device)|differential]] based systems such as the Cambridge Passenger/Commercial Vehicle Kinetic Energy Recovery System (CPC-KERS).
Xtrac and Flybrid are both licensees of Torotrak's technologies, which employ a small and sophisticated ancillary gearbox incorporating a [[continuously variable transmission]] (CVT). The CPC-KERS is similar as it also forms part of the driveline assembly. However, the whole mechanism including the flywheel sits entirely in the vehicle's hub (looking like a [[drum brake]]). In the CPC-KERS, a differential replaces the CVT and transfers torque between the flywheel, drive wheel and road wheel.
== Use in motor sport ==
<!-- Order by History, FIA, and the carmakers -->
===History=== The first of these systems to be revealed was the Flybrid.<ref name="flybrid">{{cite web | publisher = Racecar Engineering | title = F1 KERS: Flybrid | url = http://www.racecar-engineering.com/articles/f1/f1-kers-flybrid/ | date = 2008-11-18 | accessdate = 2014-06-15 }}</ref> This system weighs 24 kg (53 lbs) and has an [[energy capacity]] of 400 kJ after allowing for internal losses. A maximum power boost of 60 kW (81.6 [[Pferdestärke#PS|PS]], 80.4 HP) for 6.67 seconds is available. The 240 mm (9.4") diameter flywheel weighs 5.0 kg (11 lbs) and revolves at up to 64,500 rpm. Maximum torque at the flywheel is 18 Nm (13.3 ftlbs), and the torque at the gearbox connection is correspondingly higher for the change in speed. The system occupies a volume of 13 litres.<ref name="flybrid" /> Already in 2006, a first KERS system based on supercapacitors has been studied at EPFL (Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne) in the framework of the development of the "Formula S2000". A 180kJ system has been developed in collaboration with other institutes (Multiphysic Modeling of a Hybrid Propulsion System for a Racecar Application, A. Rufer, P. Barrade, M. Correvon and J.-F. Weber, iamf EET-2008 : European Ele-Drive Conference, International Advanced Mobility Forum, Geneva, Switzerland, 11–13 March 2008).
Two minor incidents were reported during testing of various KERS systems in {{F1|2008}}. The first occurred when the [[Red Bull Racing]] team tested their KERS battery for the first time in July: it malfunctioned and caused a fire scare that led to the team's factory being evacuated.<ref>{{cite news| title = KERS failure caused Red Bull fire scare | work =Autosport| url = http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/69199| date =17 July 2008| accessdate = 2008-07-22}}</ref> The second was less than a week later when a [[BMW in Formula One|BMW Sauber]] mechanic was given an electric shock when he touched [[Christian Klien]]'s KERS-equipped car during a test at the [[Circuito de Jerez|Jerez]] circuit.<ref>{{cite news| title =BMW mechanic escapes KERS scare | work =Autosport| url =http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/69391| date =22 July 2008| accessdate =2008-07-22}}</ref>
=== FIA === [[Formula One]] has stated that they support responsible solutions to the world's environmental challenges,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/mobility/2008/Pages/f1_environment.aspx|title=Teams Comment on F1's Environmental Future|publisher=Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|date=October 8, 2008|accessdate=2009-01-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228022048/http://www.fia.com/en-GB/mediacentre/pressreleases/mobility/2008/Pages/f1_environment.aspx|archivedate=December 28, 2008|df=}}</ref> and the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] allowed the use of {{convert|60|kW|PS bhp|abbr=on}} KERS in the regulations for the [[2009 Formula One season]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/1151088479__2009_F1_TECHNICAL_REGULATIONS.pdf | format =PDF | title =2009 Formula One Technical Regulations | publisher =Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile | date =December 22, 2006 | accessdate =2006-12-22 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080625190106/http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/1151088479__2009_F1_TECHNICAL_REGULATIONS.pdf | archivedate =June 25, 2008 | df = }}</ref> Teams began testing systems in 2008: energy can either be stored as mechanical energy (as in a flywheel) or as electrical energy (as in a battery or [[electric double-layer capacitor|supercapacitor]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/1151088479__2009_F1_TECHNICAL_REGULATIONS.pdf|format=PDF|title=2009 FORMULA ONE TECHNICAL REGULATIONS|publisher=Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|author=FIA management|date=December 22, 2006|accessdate=2008-07-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625190106/http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/1151088479__2009_F1_TECHNICAL_REGULATIONS.pdf|archivedate=June 25, 2008|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Kimi Raikkonen 2009 Belgium 3.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kimi Räikkönen]] took the lead of the [[2009 Belgian Grand Prix]] with a KERS-aided overtake and subsequently won the race.]] With the introduction of KERS in the 2009 season, only four teams used it at some point in the season: [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]], [[Renault F1|Renault]], [[BMW in Formula One|BMW]] and [[McLaren]]. Eventually, during the season, Renault and BMW stopped using the system. [[McLaren|Vodafone McLaren Mercedes]] became the first team to win an F1 GP using a KERS equipped car when [[Lewis Hamilton]] won the Hungarian Grand Prix on July 26, 2009. Their second KERS equipped car finished fifth. At the following race, Lewis Hamilton became the first driver to take pole position with a KERS car, his teammate, [[Heikki Kovalainen]] qualifying second. This was also the first instance of an all KERS front row. On August 30, 2009, [[Kimi Räikkönen]] won the Belgian Grand Prix with his KERS equipped Ferrari. It was the first time that KERS contributed directly to a race victory, with second placed [[Giancarlo Fisichella]] claiming "Actually, I was quicker than Kimi. He only took me because of KERS at the beginning".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8229449.stm|title=Raikkonen wins exciting Spa duel|publisher=BBC|date=August 30, 2009|accessdate=2009-08-30|first=Chris|last=Whyatt}}</ref>
Although KERS was still legal in F1 in the 2010 season, all the teams had agreed not to use it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.formula1.com/inside_f1/understanding_the_sport/8763.html |title=Kinetic Energy Recovery Systems (KERS) |publisher=Formula One |accessdate=2010-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706214811/http://www.formula1.com/inside_f1/understanding_the_sport/8763.html |archivedate=6 July 2010}}</ref> New rules for the 2011 F1 season which raised the minimum weight limit of the car and driver by 20 kg to 640 kg,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2010/12/11603.html |title=http://www.formula1.com/news/headlines/2010/12/11603.html |publisher=Formula 1 |accessdate=2010-12-04}}</ref> along with the [[Formula One Teams Association|FOTA]] teams agreeing to the use of KERS devices once more, meant that KERS returned for the 2011 season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8756430.stm|title=Changes made to F1l|publisher=BBC|date=23 June 2010|accessdate=23 June 2010|first=Andrew|last=Benson}}</ref> Use of KERS was still optional as in the 2009 season; and at the start of the 2011 season three teams elected not to use it.<ref name="3teams">{{cite web|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/team-lotus-virgin-hrt-f1-to-start-2011-without-kers-30389.html |title=Team Lotus, Virgin, HRT F1 to Start 2011 Without KERS |publisher=Autoevolution |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-06-01 }}</ref>
[[WilliamsF1]] developed their own flywheel-based KERS system but decided not to use it in their F1 cars due to packaging issues, and have instead developed their own electrical KERS system. However, they set up Williams Hybrid Power to sell their developments. In 2012 it was announced that the [[Audi R18#R18 e-tron quattro|Audi Le Mans R18 hybrid cars]] would use Williams Hybrid Power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/97739|title=Audi unveils hybrid R18 e-tron quattro in Munich|date=29 February 2012|work=[[Autosport]]|accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref>
Since 2014, the power capacity of the KERS units were increased from {{convert|60|kW|bhp}} to {{convert|120|kW|bhp}}. This was introduced to balance the sport's move from 2.4 litre V8 engines to 1.6 litre V6 TURBO engines.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/formula_one/13878359.stm |title=Formula 1 delays introduction of 'green' engines until 2014 |publisher=BBC |date= 2011-06-29|accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref>
=== Working diagram for KERS ===
[[File:Kinetic Energy Recovery System.gif|thumb|center|upright=3.0|The operation process of KERS in Formula One]]
=== Autopart makers === [[File:KERS flywheel.jpg|thumb|right|A KERS flywheel.]] [[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]] Motorsport Service is developing a KERS for use in motor racing. These electricity storage systems for hybrid and engine functions include a [[lithium-ion battery]] with scalable capacity or a flywheel, a four to eight kilogram [[electric motor]] (with a maximum power level of 60 kW (81 hp)), as well as the KERS controller for power and battery management. Bosch also offers a range of electric hybrid systems for commercial and light-duty applications.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = Green Car Congress | title = Bosch Developing Modular KERS Systems for Range of Motorsport Applications | url = http://www.greencarcongress.com/2008/11/bosch-developin.html | date = 2008-11-18 | accessdate = 2010-04-27 }}</ref>
=== Carmakers ===
Several automakers have been testing KERS systems.<ref>http://www.carmondo.de/blog/2008/07/03/honda-und-bmw-mit-formel-1-hybriden/ {{de icon}}</ref> At the [[2008 1000 km of Silverstone|2008 1000 km of Silverstone]], Peugeot Sport unveiled the [[Peugeot 908 HDi FAP|Peugeot 908 HY]], a [[hybrid electric vehicle|hybrid electric]] variant of the diesel 908, with KERS. Peugeot planned to campaign the car in the [[2009 Le Mans Series season]], although it was not allowed to score championship points.<ref name="908HY">{{cite web | url = http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/273697/peugeot-reveal-hybrid-racer-for-2009.html | title = Peugeot Sport Hybrid | publisher = Racecar Engineering | date = 13 September 2008 | accessdate = 2008-09-13 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090113183348/http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/273697/peugeot-reveal-hybrid-racer-for-2009.html | archivedate = 13 January 2009 | df = }}</ref>
[[McLaren|Vodafone McLaren Mercedes]] began testing of their KERS in September 2008 at the Jerez test track in preparation for the 2009 F1 season, although at that time it was not yet known if they would be operating an electrical or mechanical system.<ref>{{cite web |author=Lawrence Butcher |url=http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/274178/mclaren-on-track-with-kers.html |title=F1 KERS; McLaren on track with KERS | People |publisher=Racecar Engineering |date=2008-09-18 |accessdate=2010-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922221623/http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/274178/mclaren-on-track-with-kers.html |archivedate=2008-09-22 |df= }}</ref> In November 2008 it was announced that [[Freescale Semiconductor]] would collaborate with [[McLaren Electronic Systems]] to further develop its KERS for [[McLaren (racing)|McLaren]]'s Formula One car from 2010 onwards. Both parties believed this collaboration would improve McLaren's KERS system and help the system to transfer its technology to road cars.<ref>[http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/72085 McLaren to work with Freescale on KERS] November 12, 2008</ref>
[[Toyota]] has used a [[electric double-layer capacitor|supercapacitor]] for regeneration on [[Toyota Supra|Supra]] HV-R hybrid race car that won the Tokachi 24-Hour endurance race in July 2007. This Supra became the first hybrid car in the history of motorsport to win such a race.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2007/07/toyota-hybrid-r.html |title=Toyota Hybrid Race Car Wins Tokachi 24-Hour Race; In-Wheel Motors and Supercapacitors |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2007-07-17 |accessdate=2010-09-17}}</ref>
At the [[North American International Auto Show|NAIAS 2011]], [[Porsche]] unveiled a RSR variant of their [[Porsche 918]] concept car which uses a flywheel-based KERS that sits beside the driver in the passenger compartment and boosts the dual electric motors driving the front wheels and the 565 BHP V8 gasoline engine driving the rear to a combined power output of 767 BHP. This system has many problems including the imbalance caused to the vehicle due to the flywheel. Porsche is currently developing an electrical storage system.<ref>[http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/porsche-918-rsr-have-flywheel-will-race/?ref=automobiles] 918 RSR: Have Flywheel, Will Race January 10, 2011,</ref>
In 2011, [[Mazda]] has announced i-ELOOP, a system which uses a variable-voltage [[alternator]] to convert kinetic energy to electric power during deceleration. The energy, stored in a [[Electric double-layer capacitor|double-layer capacitor]], is used to supply power needed by vehicle electrical systems. When used in conjunction with Mazda's [[start-stop system]], i-Stop, the company claims fuel savings of up to 10%.<ref>Kurt Ernst. [http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1069983_mazdas-regenerative-braking-system-switches-batteries-for-capacitors Mazda's regenerative braking system switches batteries for capacitors]. 2011</ref>
[[Robert Bosch GmbH|Bosch]] and [[PSA Peugeot Citroën]] have developed a hybrid system that use hydraulics as a way to transfer energy to and from a [[Compressed air energy storage|compressed nitrogen]] tank. An up to 45% reduction in fuel consumption is claimed, corresponding to 2.9l/100 km (81 mpg, 69 g CO<sub>2</sub>/km) on the [[New European Driving Cycle|NEDC]] cycle for a compact frame like [[Peugeot 208]]. The system is claimed to be much more affordable than competing electric and flywheel systems and was expected on road cars by 2016 but was abandoned in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/01/psabosch-20130122.html|title=PSA Peugeot Citroën and Bosch developing hydraulic hybrid powertrain for passenger cars; 30% reduction in fuel consumption in NEDC, up to 45% urban; B-segment application in 2016|website=Green Car Congress}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usinenouvelle.com/article/hybrid-air-pourquoi-psa-se-degonfle.N307190|title=Hybrid Air : pourquoi PSA se dégonfle - Innovations Auto|last=Nouvelle|first=L'Usine|date=2015-01-12|work=usinenouvelle.com/|access-date=2018-08-26|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
=== Motorcycles ===
[[KTM]] racing boss [[Harald Bartol]] revealed that the factory raced with a secret kinetic energy recovery system fitted to [[Tomoyoshi Koyama|Tommy Koyama]]'s motorcycle during the 2008 season-ending 125cc [[Valencian Community motorcycle Grand Prix|Valencian Grand Prix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crash.net/MotoGP/News/142605/1/ktm_beats_f1_with_secret_kers_debut.html |title=KTM beats F1 with secret KERS debut! | Feb 2009 |publisher=Crash.Net |date=2009-02-04 |accessdate=2010-08-14}}</ref> The system was later ruled illegal and thus was banned.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} The Lit C-1 electric motorcycle will also use a KERS as a regenerative braking system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://litmotors.com/c1/|title=C-1|publisher=Lit Motors|accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref>
=== Bicycles ===
KERS is also possible on a bicycle. The [[EPA]], working with students from the University of Michigan, developed the hydraulic Regenerative Brake Launch Assist (RBLA)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.epa.gov/otaq/technology/web/html/research-hhb.html|title=Hydraulic Hybrid Bicycle Research- Clean Automotive Technology - Transportation and Air Quality- US EPA|first=US|last=EPA|website=archive.epa.gov}}</ref>
This has also been demonstrated by mounting a flywheel on a bike frame and connecting it with a [[continuously variable transmission|CVT]] to the back wheel. By shifting the gear, 20% of the kinetic energy can be stored in the flywheel, ready to give an acceleration boost by reshifting the gear.<ref>{{citation | title = Boost Your Bike | publisher = Science Friday | url = http://ec2-23-21-117-9.compute-1.amazonaws.com/video/08/12/2011/boost-your-bike.html | date = 2011-08-12 | accessdate = 2017-03-18}}</ref>
Experimental Machinist Douglas Goncz connected three ultracapacitor packs on an electric hub equipped recumbent bicycle in series/parallel with a 4PDT toggle switch in 2007 and described the resulting MObile Experimental Physics Educational Demonstrator (MOEPED) and its 19 kJ "electric flywheel" in a newsgroup posting to the moderated newsgroup sci.physics.research dated 11/9 of that year titled "MOEPED Update" and in other newsgroup threads under the keyword "MOEPED". In parallel, the packs were a regenerative brake; in series, they were a boost source. The vehicle remained in use so equipped until 2010. It was surplus disposed in 2013.
=== Races ===
[[Automobile Club de l'Ouest]], the organizer behind the annual [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] event and the [[Le Mans Series]], has promoted the use of kinetic energy recovery systems in the [[Le Mans Prototype|LMP1]] class since the late 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemans.org/sport/sport/reglements/ressources/auto_2008/cdc_reglement_lmp_fr_gb_2008.pdf |format=PDF |title=ACO Technical Regulations 2008 for Prototype "LM"P1 and "LM"P2 classes, page 3 |publisher=Automobile Club de l'Ouest (ACO) |date=20 December 2007 |accessdate=2008-01-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625190107/http://www.lemans.org/sport/sport/reglements/ressources/auto_2008/cdc_reglement_lmp_fr_gb_2008.pdf |archivedate=25 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Peugeot was the first manufacturer to unveil a fully functioning LMP1 car in the form of the 908 HY at the 2008 Autosport 1000 km race at Silverstone.<ref>{{cite web |author=Sam Collins |url=http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/273697/peugeot-reveal-hybrid-racer-for-2009.html |title=Peugeot Sport Hybrid | People |publisher=Racecar Engineering |date=2008-09-13 |accessdate=2010-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113183348/http://www.racecar-engineering.com/news/people/273697/peugeot-reveal-hybrid-racer-for-2009.html |archivedate=2009-01-13 |df= }}</ref>
The [[2011 24 Hours of Le Mans]] saw Hope Racing enter with a Flybrid Systems mechanical KERS, to be the first car ever to compete at the event with a hybrid. The system consisted of high speed slipping clutches which transfer torque to and from the vehicle, coupled to a 60,000 rpm flywheel.
Audi and Toyota both developed LMP1 cars with kinetic energy recovery systems for the 2012 and 2013 24 Hours of Le Mans. The [[Audi R18#R18 e-tron quattro|Audi R18 e-tron quattro]] uses a [[flywheel]]-based system, while the [[Toyota TS030 Hybrid]] uses a [[supercapacitor]]-based system. When Porsche announced its return to Le Mans in 2014, it also unveiled an LMP1 car with a kinetic energy recovery system. The [[Porsche 919 Hybrid]], introduced in 2014, uses a battery system, in contrast to the previous Porsche 911 GT3 R Hybrid that used a flywheel system.

{{short description|A series of shallow, slow, counter-rotating vortices at the ocean's surface aligned with the wind}} [[File:Langmuir Circulation.jpg|right|thumb|Langmuir circulation]] [[File:Rodeo Lagoon From Trail.JPG|thumb|right|White streaks in this lagoon are due to the Langmuir circulation.]] [[File:Lines of sargassum Sargasso Sea.jpg|thumb|right|These lines of [[sargassum]] can stretch for miles along the surface. The clumps of floating [[algae]] are often concentrated by the strong winds and wave action associated with the [[Gulf Stream]].]]
In [[physical oceanography]], '''Langmuir circulation''' consists of a series of shallow, slow, counter-rotating [[vortex|vortices]] at the ocean's surface aligned with the wind. These circulations are developed when wind blows steadily over the sea surface. [[Irving Langmuir]] discovered this phenomenon after observing [[windrow]]s of seaweed in the [[Sargasso Sea]] in 1927.<ref> {{Citation | publisher = Butterworth-Heinemann | isbn = 9780750652780 | author = Open University | edition = 2nd | title = Ocean Circulation | year = 2001 }} </ref> Langmuir circulations circulate within the [[mixed layer]]; however, it is not yet so clear how strongly they can cause mixing at the base of the mixed layer. <ref name="thorpe2004"> {{citation | last1=Thorpe | first1=S.A. | year=2004 | title=Langmuir circulation| journal=Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics | volume=36 | pages=55–79 | doi= 10.1146/annurev.fluid.36.052203.071431 |bibcode = 2004AnRFM..36...55T }} </ref>
== Theory ==
The driving force of these circulations is an interaction of the mean flow with wave averaged flows of the surface waves. [[Stokes drift|Stokes drift velocity]] of the waves stretches and tilts the vorticity of the flow near the surface. The production of vorticity in the upper ocean is balanced by downward (often turbulent) diffusion <math>
u_T</math>. For a flow driven by a wind <math>	au</math> characterized by [[friction velocity]] <math>u_*</math> the ratio of vorticity diffusion and production defines the Langmuir number <ref name="thorpe2004"/> : <math> \mathrm{La} = \sqrt{ rac{
u^3_Tk^6}{\sigma a^2u^2_*k^4}} \ \mathrm{or}\ \sqrt{ rac{
u_T^3 eta^6}{u^2_*S_0 eta^3}} </math> where the first definition is for a monochromatic wave field of amplitude <math>a</math>, frequency <math>\sigma</math>, and wavenumber <math>k</math> and the second uses a generic inverse length scale <math> eta</math>, and Stokes velocity scale <math>S_0</math>. This is exemplified by the [[Craik–Leibovich vortex force|Craik–Leibovich equations]]<ref> {{citation | last1=Craik | first1=A.D.D. | last2=Leibovich |first2=S. | year=1976 | title=A Rational model for Langmuir circulations| journal=Journal of Fluid Mechanics | volume=73 | pages=401–426 | doi= 10.1017/S0022112076001420 |bibcode = 1976JFM....73..401C }} </ref> which are an approximation of the [[generalized Lagrangian mean|Lagrangian mean]].<ref> {{citation | last1=Andrews | first1=D.G. | last2=McIntyre |first2=M.E. | year=1978 | title=An exact theory of nonlinear waves on a Lagrangian-mean flow| journal=Journal of Fluid Mechanics | volume=89 | pages=609–646 | doi= 10.1017/S0022112078002773 |bibcode = 1978JFM....89..609A }} </ref><ref> {{citation | last1=Leibovich |first1=S. | year=1980 | title=On wave-current interactions theories of Langmuir circulations| journal=Journal of Fluid Mechanics | volume=99 | pages=715–724 | doi= 10.1017/S0022112080000857 |bibcode = 1980JFM....99..715L }} </ref> In the [[Boussinesq approximation (buoyancy)|Boussinesq approximation]] the governing equations can be written : <math>  rac{\partial u_i}{\partial t} +u_j
abla_ju_i =  egin{array}{l} -2\epsilon_{ijk}\Omega_j\left(u^s_k+u_kight) -
abla_i\left( rac{P}{ho_0}+ rac{1}{2}u^s_ju^s_j+u^s_ju_jight)\ +\epsilon_{ijk}u^s_j\epsilon_{klm}
abla_lu_m +g_i rac{ho}{ho_0} +
abla_j

u</math> is the viscosity, and <math>\kappa</math> is the diffusivity.
In the open ocean conditions where there may not be a dominant length scale controlling the scale of the Langmuir cells the concept of [[Langmuir Turbulence]] is advanced. <ref> {{citation | last1=McWilliams | first1=J. | last2=Sullivan |first2=P. | last3=Moeng | first3=C. | year=1997 | title=Langmuir turbulence in the ocean| journal=Journal of Fluid Mechanics | volume=334 | pages=1–30 | doi= 10.1017/S0022112096004375 | bibcode=1997JFM...334....1M }} </ref>
== Observations == The circulation has been observed to be between 0°–20° to the right of the wind in the [[northern hemisphere]] <ref> {{citation |last=Stewart |first=Robert H. |title=Introduction To Physical Oceanography |year=2002 |edition=Fall 2002 }} </ref> and the [[helix]] forming bands of [[divergence]] and [[Convergence zone|convergence]] at the surface. At the convergence zones, there are commonly concentrations of floating seaweed, foam and debris along these bands. Along these divergent zones, the ocean surface is typically clear of debris since diverging currents force material out of this zone and into adjacent converging zones. At the surface the circulation will set a current from the divergence zone to the convergence zone and the spacing between these zones are of the order of {{convert|1|–|300|m|ft|abbr=on|sigfig=1}}. Below convergence zones narrow jets of downward flow form and the magnitude of the current will be comparable to the horizontal flow. The downward propagation will typically be in the order of meters or tenths of meters and will not penetrate the [[pycnocline]]. The [[upwelling]] is less intense and takes place over a wider band under the divergence zone. In wind speeds ranging from {{convert|2|-|12|m/s|abbr=on}} the maximum vertical velocity ranged from {{convert|2|-|10|cm/s|abbr=on}} with a ratio of down-welling to wind velocities ranging from −0.0025 to −0.0085. <ref> {{citation | last1=Leibovich | first1=S. | year=1983 | title=The form and dynamics of Langmuir circulations| journal=Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics | volume=15 | pages=391–427 | doi= 10.1146/annurev.fl.15.010183.002135 |bibcode = 1983AnRFM..15..391L }} </ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=July 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2017}} {{Tone|date=September 2018}} {{Research paper|date=September 2018}} }}
{{cleanup rewrite|date=December 2015}}
'''Lean product development''' ('''LPD''') is a [[Lean manufacturing|lean]] approach to counter the challenges of [[New product development|product development]], notably: * Lack of innovative solutions * Long [[development cycle]] times * Many [[redevelopment]] cycles * High development costs * Long [[production cycle]] times * High [[production cost]]s
==See also== *[[Design for lean manufacturing]] *[[Muntzing]] *[[Toyota Production System]]
==History of lean product development== [[Toyota]] started its journey with lean product development<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kimoto|first1=Shoji|title=Quest for the Dawn|date=1991|publisher=Dougherty Co|isbn=1878150014|edition=1st}}</ref> at Toyota Loom Works (see [[History of Toyota]]). Their early approach is notably different from the lean manufacturing that became famous through the book "[[The Machine That Changed the World (book)|The Machine that changed the world]]".
When Toyota started manufacturing cars, there was a difference in manufacturing conditions between Japan and the USA. Toyota had few educated engineers and little prior experience. Car companies in US employed a well-educated work force in the cities and benefited from the research and student skill-sets of established engineering schools. To tackle this shortfall in knowledge and experience, Toyota conducted an incremental approach to development that built on their existing knowledge and became the basis of the lean systems Toyota uses today.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ward|first1=Allen|title=Lean Product and Process Development|publisher=LEI|isbn=978-1934109137|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sato|first1=Masaaki|title=The Toyota Leaders: An Executive Guide|date=December 16, 2008|publisher=Vertical|isbn=978-1934287231|pages=40–45|edition=1st}}</ref>
Allen Ward studied Toyota’s lean product development system and found parallels with the US [[airplane industry]]. For instance, the Wright brothers’ method<ref>{{cite book|last1=Melvin|first1=Bob|title=Knowledge Based Product Development: A Practical Guide|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=1492705969|page=16}}</ref> of constructing their airplanes became one of the legacies they passed on to the aviation industry. This approach enabled the USA to create one of World War II's most successful fighter planes from scratch in the short span of six months. After the war, Toyota incorporated many of the airline industry's findings into its own product development methodology.
==Differences between lean product development and lean production== While some basic principles and guidelines are applicable across lean product development and lean production (such as waste reduction), many applications of lean process for development have focused more on the production approach.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lean.enst.fr/wiki/pub/Lean/LesPublications/LeanDevBalleBalle.pdf|title=Lean Development|publisher=Business Strategy Review|last2=Ballé|first2=Freddy|pages=17–22|last1=Ballé|first1=Michael}}</ref>
The purpose of production is to manufacture products reliably within margins of control. The flow of value is physically evident, and the link between cause and effect is easy to see. For example, feedback on adjusting the speed of production is immediately realized in an increase or decrease in rejected items. Any decisions made must be based on best practice.
On the other hand, the purpose of product development is to design new products that improve the lives of customers. This is a complex space where the flow of value can only be discerned at an abstract level and where cause and effect might be separated by time and space. For example, feedback on the decision to design a certain feature will not be received until the product has been built and is in the hands of the customer. This means that decisions are made on short-cycle experimentation, prototyping, set-based design, and emergent practice. A premium is placed on creating reusable knowledge and reducing risk at handover points.
An essential point about these differences is summarized in the advice Jim Womack gives Harley Davidson: "''Don't try to bring lean manufacturing upstream to product development. The application of Lean in product development and manufacturing are different. Some aspects may look similar, but they are not! Be leery of an expert with experience in lean manufacturing that claims to know product development''" <ref>{{cite book|last1=Oosterwal|first1=Dantar|title=The Lean Machine|date=January 13, 2010|publisher=Productivity Press|isbn=978-0814432884|pages=131–132}}</ref>
The most common high level concepts associated with lean product development are: # [[Knowledge creation|Creation of re-usable knowledge]]. Knowledge is created and maintained so that it can be leveraged for successive products or iterations. # Set-based [[concurrent engineering]]. Different stages of product development run simultaneously rather than consecutively to decrease development time, improve productivity, and reduce costs. # Teams of responsible experts. Lean product development organizations develop cross-functional teams and reward competence building in teams and individuals. # Cadence and pull. Managers of lean product development organizations develop autonomous teams, where engineers plan their own work and work their own plans. # Visual management. [[Information graphics|Visualization]] is a main enabler of lean product development.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Holmdahl|first1=Lars|title=Visual Management in Lean Product Development|isbn=978-91-979196-1-6|pages=1–15|url=http://www.larsholmdahl.com}}</ref> # Entrepreneurial system designer. The lean product development organization makes one person responsible for the engineering and aesthetic design, and market and business success, of the product.
== Results of lean product development == Lean product development has been claimed to produce the following results: * Increase innovation ten-fold<ref name=ward>Allen Ward - Lean Product and Process Development</ref> * Increase introduction of new products 400%-500% <ref name=ward/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Oosterwal|first1=Dantar|title=The Lean Machine|date=January 13, 2010|publisher=Productivity Press|isbn=978-0814432884|pages=237–240}}</ref>
Companies such as Toyota can attribute their success to lean product development. In 2000, Toyota launched 14 new products, a larger product line than GM's entire product offering. At that point, Toyota had just 70,000 employees while GM had more than five times as many.<ref name=ward/>
== Applicability of lean product development ==
Researchers<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ottosson|first1=Stig|title=Handbook in Innovation Management|date=2006|publisher=www.complexityforum.com|url=http://www.complexityforum.com}}</ref> divide product development projects accordingly to their need drivers: * '''Wished''': there is no such product on the market, only a wish for such a product. These projects can be on the edge of what is possible to do. * '''Wanted''': there are only a few basic similar products on the market that usually require improvement. * '''Needed''': there are enough products in existence so knowledge about this is abundant on the market.
For example, the mobile phone was a ''Wanted'' product in the 1990s because it was on the leading edge of technology. Today it is regarded as a ''Needed'' product. It is common in the market. There is enough knowledge in the public domain so that even small companies can make a good mobile phone.
Product development methods can be classified according to whether they are focused on handling stable or non-stable conditions. Lean product development is a dynamic method of product development that handles unstable conditions.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Holmdahl|first1=Lars|title=Visual Management in Lean Product Development|isbn=978-91-979196-1-6|pages=18–20}}</ref>
The influence of need drivers and stability (or lack of stability) on product development are illustrated in the table below.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=September 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! !! Short !! Medium !! Long |- | '''Needed'''|| stable|| stable|| moderately non-stable |- | '''Wanted'''|| moderately non-stable|| moderately non-stable|| non-stable |- | '''Wished'''|| non-stable|| non-stable|| non-stable |}

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of Lepidoptera that feed on ''Ipomoea''}} '''''[[Ipomoea]]''''' [[morning glories]] are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species, including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on ''Ipomoea''
[[Bedelliidae]] * ''[[Bedellia minor]]'' * ''[[Bedellia terenodes]]'' [[Bucculatricidae]] * ''[[Bucculatrix univoca]]'' – recorded on [[water spinach]] (''I. aquatica'') [[Noctuidae]] *''[[Schinia simplex]]'' – recorded on [[bush morning glory]] (''I. leptophylla'')
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Ipomoea'' and other plants

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Tulostoma'' species}} [[File:Tulostoma 75374.jpg|thumb|300px|right|''Tulostoma'' spp.]] ''[[Tulostoma]]'' is a [[genus]] of over 100 species of [[fungi]] in the family [[Agaricaceae]]. Commonly known as stalked puffballs, the [[cosmopolitan distribution|cosmopolitan]] genus consists of species which produce small [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]], characterized by stalks inserted in a socket at the base of the spherical spore-sac opened by a small and apical mouth. The spore-sac contains [[gleba]], a mixture of spores and associated cells; at maturity, the spores are released through one or more apical pores. ''Tulostoma'' species prefer [[xeric]] [[microhabitat]]s, [[savannah]]s and [[desert]]s, and are [[saprobic]]—obtaining nutrients by decomposing roots, buried wood and other organic material of plant origin.<ref name="Miller 1988"/>
The following list of 102 species is compiled from [[Jorge Eduardo Wright]]'s 1987 world [[monograph]] on the ''Tulostomatales'', as well as reports of new taxa described in the literature published since then. Wright included 139 species in his monograph, including 47 "doubtful or critical" species. New species have since been reported from Spain (1992),<ref name="Moreno 1992"/> Mexico (1995),<ref name="Moreno 1995"/> Venezuela (2000),<ref name="Moreno 2002"/> Tunisia (2002),<ref name="Moreno 2002"/> China (2005),<ref name="Fan 2005"/> and Argentina.<ref name="Caffot 2011"/>
==Infrageneric classification== Czech mycologist [[Zdeněk Pouzar]] elaborated an infrageneric (below the level of genus) system of [[classification (biology)|classification]] for ''Tulostoma'' species in his 1958 [[monograph]] of European taxa.<ref name="Pilát 1958"/> Wright expanded and revised Pouzar's classification system to include all known species: ;Subgenus ''Tulostoma'' :Series ''Tubulares'' ::Section ''Brumalia'' ::Section ''Hyphales'' ::Section ''Granulosae'' ::Section ''Volvulata'' ::Section ''Meristostoma'' :Series ''Fimbriata'' ::Section ''Fimbriata'' ::Section ''Poculata'' ::Section ''Exasperata'' ::Section ''Dubiostoma'' ::Section ''Rickiana'' ;Subgenus ''Lacerostoma'' ::Section ''Lacerata''

{{for|the director|Lü Ban (director)}} {{Chinese name|[[Lu (surname 鲁)|Lu]]}} {{chinese |pic=File:Luban sculpture weifang 2010 06 06.jpg |piccap=Sculpture of Lu Ban in [[Weifang]] |s={{linktext|鲁|班}} |w=Lu Pan |t={{linktext|魯|班}} |p=Lǔ Bān |altname=Gongshu Yizhi |t2={{linktext|公輸|依|智}} |s2={{linktext|公输|依|智}} |p2=Gōngshū Yīzhì |w2=Kung-shu I-chih |altname3=Gongshu Ban |t3={{linktext|公輸|班}}
{{linktext|公輸|般}} |s3={{linktext|公输|班}}
{{linktext|公输|般}}|p3=Gōngshū Bān |w3=Kung-shu Pan |altname4=Gongshu Pan |t4={{linktext|公輸|盘}} |s4={{linktext|公输|盘}} |p4=Gōngshū Pán |w4=Kung-shu P‘an }} '''Lu Ban'''{{efn|Known as '''Lo Pan''' in Cantonese contexts. Sometimes spelled as '''Lu Pan'''.}} ({{circa|lk=no|507}}–444{{nbsp}}BC){{sfnp|Yan|2007}}{{citation|contribution-url=http://www.cultural-china.com/chinaWH/html/en/Kaleidoscope56bye237.html |contribution=Lu Ban |url=http://www.cultural-china.com |title=Cultural China |location=Shanghai |publisher=Shanghai Digital Century Network |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210011150/http://www.cultural-china.com/ |archivedate=2014-12-10 |df= }}. was a Chinese carpenter, engineer and inventor during the Zhou Dynasty. He is revered as the [[Chinese folk religion|Chinese]] [[Chinese gods|god]] (patron) of builders and contractors.{{anchor|History|Biography}} ==Life== Lu Ban was born in the [[ancient Chinese states|state]] of [[State of Lu|Lu]], possibly at [[Dunhuang]],''[[Youyang Zazu]]'', Vol. XXIV.{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} to family of carpenters or artisans{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} during the [[Spring and Autumn period]] of the [[Zhou dynasty]]. His original name was {{nowrap|'''Gongshu Yizhi'''.}} He was also referred to as {{nowrap|'''Gongshu Ban'''}} or '''Pan'''. He was supposed to have been an indifferent pupil until his love of learning was kindled by the scholar [[Zi Xia]].{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} He later learned woodworking from Bao Laodong.{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} The great demand for his work supposedly compelled him to invent or improve a number of carpenter's tools—the [[saw]], the [[carpenter's square|square]], the [[plane (tool)|planer]], the [[drill]], the [[shovel]], and an ink marking tool—to complete his many projects more quickly.{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} His wife was also credited with inventing the [[umbrella]] in order to permit him to work in inclement weather.{{sfnp|Yan|2007}} ==Inventions== According to tradition, he was responsible for several inventions:''[[Mozi]]'', Ch. 49 & 50. * Cloud ladder—a mobile, counterweighted siege ladder.{{efn|{{lang-zh|公輸盤為楚造雲梯之械，成，將以攻宋。}} "Gongshu Ban had completed the construction of Cloud ladders for the State of Chu and was going to attack the State of Song with them."[http://ctext.org/mozi/gong-shu#n877 ''Mozi'', Ch. 50, Para. 1].}} * Grappling hooks and ram—implements for naval warfare.{{efn|{{lang-zh|公輸子自鲁南遊楚，焉始為舟戰之器，作为鈎强之備，退者鈎之，進者强之，量其鈎强之長，而製為之兵。楚之兵節，越之兵不節，楚人因此若埶，亟敗越人。}} "Gongshuzi came south from the State of Lu to the State of Chu, and began making implements for naval warfare which consisted of grappling hooks and rams. When the enemy were retreating they used the hooks. And when the enemy were advancing they employed the rams. And the weapons were made according to the length of these hooks and rams. The weapons of the State of Chu thus were all standardized, and those of the State of Yue were not. And, with this advantage, the people of Chu greatly defeated the people of Yue."[http://ctext.org/mozi/lus-question#n874 ''Mozi'', Ch. 49, Para. 20].}} * Wooden bird—a non-powered, flying, wooden bird which could stay in the air for three days. It has been suggested to be a prototype of a kite.{{efn|{{lang-zh|公輸子削竹木以為鵲，成而飛之，三日不下。}} "Gongshuzi constructed a bird from bamboo and wood and when it was completed he flew it. It stayed up [in the air] for three days."[http://ctext.org/mozi/lus-question#n875 ''Mozi'', Ch. 49, Para. 21].}} Other inventions were also attributed to him, such as a lifting implement to assist with burial,''[[Liji]]'', Ch. 4. a wooden horse carriage and coachman,''Lunheng'', Ch. 85, by Wang Chong (b. 27). a pedal-powered cycle,{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2010/03/24/was-this-the-worlds-first-ever-cycle-189288/|title=Was this the world’s first-ever cycle?|author=|date=24 March 2010|website=metro.co.uk}} and other woodworking mentioned in various texts, which thereafter led Lu Ban to be acknowledged as a master craftsman: * ''The Book of Lineages'' (''[[Shiben]]''), written c. the 3rd century BC. * ''The Tales of the Marvellous'' (述異記), by Ren Fang, written c. the 5th century AD. * ''The Records of Origin on Things and Affairs'' (事物紀原), by Gao Cheng, written c. the 11th century. * ''The Origin on Things'' (物原), by Luo Qi, written c. the 15th century. * ''The Treatise of Lu Ban'' (鲁班經), attributed to Lu Ban, written in the 13th, 14th, or 15th century. ==Legacy== Lu Ban is revered as the god of carpentry and masonry in [[Chinese folk religion]]. His personality is assumed by the master carpenter involved in the construction of houses among the [[Dong people|Dong]].{{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tnXfBQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |title=Architecture and Movement: The Dynamic Experience of Buildings and Landscapes |editor=Peter Blundell Jones |editor2=Mark Meagher |location=Abingdon |publisher=Routledge |date=2015 |last=Kong |first=Derong |authormask=Kong Derong |contribution=House Construction among the Dong |contribution-url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tnXfBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA220 |p=[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tnXfBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA229 229] }}. He is sometimes counted among the [[Five Kings of the Water Immortals]], [[Taoism in China|Taoist]] [[water gods]] invoked by sailors for protection while carrying out journeys.{{citation |contribution=臺灣水仙尊王崇祀之溯源 [''Táiwān Shuǐxiān Zūnwáng Chóngsì zhī Sùyuán'', Tracing the Worship of the Honorable Water Immortal Kings] |last=Huang |first=A-yu |authormask=Huang A-yu |title=''人文研究期刊 [''Rénwén Yánjiū Qīkān'','' Humanities Periodical''], No. 8'' |date=December 2010 |pp=81–112 |contribution-url=http://www.airitilibrary.com/Publication/alDetailedMesh?DocID=19967934-201012-201307160003-201307160003-81-112 }}. {{zh icon}}{{nbsp}}& {{en icon}} He is referenced in a number of [[chengyu|Chinese idioms]]. The Chinese equivalent of "teaching one's grandmother to suck eggs" is to "brandish one's axe at Lu Ban's door".{{harvp|Needham|1994|p=[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PehoSnJfstUC&pg=PA20 20]}} His cultural companion is the stone worker Wang Er, who lived around the same time. The modern artist [[Shi Lu]] has claimed that Lu Ban was an alias of his contemporary [[Confucius]], but this seems dubious.{{citation |p=[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=y_VLkX4tjAMC&pg=PA83 83] |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=y_VLkX4tjAMC&printsec=frontcover |title=Art in Turmoil: The Chinese Cultural Revolution, 1966–76 |editor=Richard King |editor2=Ralph Croizier |editor3=Zheng Shengtian |editor4=Scott Watson |display-editors=0 |publisher=[[University of British Columbia|UBC]] Press |location=Vancouver |date=2010 |last=Hawks |first=Shelley Drake |contribution=Summoning Confucius: Inside Shi Lu's Imagination |contribution-url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=y_VLkX4tjAMC&pg=PA58 }}. ==See also== * [[Lo Pan Temple]] in Hong Kong ==Notes== {{Noteslist}} ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{citation |last=Du |first=Shiran |authormask=Du Shiran |title=Biographies of Ancient Chinese Scientists Series One: [http://www.xys.org/xys/ebooks/others/science/history/china/luban.txt Lu Ban] | publisher=Kexue Chubanshe | location=Beijing | pages=22–25 | year=1992 | isbn=7-03-002926-7 }}. * {{citation |last=Le Chevoir |first=Patrick |contribution=L'Unite de Mesure de Lu Ban (魯班尺): Une Unité de Mesure Conceptuelle au Service des Statuaires d'Yilan (宜蘭市) à Taiwan, Vol. III-1, [2-14] |title=Anthroepotes |date=1998 |contribution-url=http://www.lexiaolong.com/html/francais/016lubanchi.html }}. {{fr icon}} * {{citation |last=Li |first=Shaoyuan |authormask=Li Shaoyuan |author2=Zhao Beizhi |display-authors=1 |title=Stories of Chinese Scientist and Inventors | publisher=Jindun Publishing House | pages=1–8 | location=Beijing | year=1996 | isbn=7-5082-0168-X }}. * {{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PehoSnJfstUC&printsec=frontcover |title=The Shorter Science and Civilization of China, ''Vol. 4'' |last=Needham |first=Joseph |editor=Colin A. Ronan |display-editors=0 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=[[Cambridge, England|Cambridge]] |date=1994 }}. * {{citation |last=Wang |first=Fu |authormask=Wang Fu| title=Records of Lu Ban: China's Earliest Inventor: Lu Ban | publisher=Zhongguo Kexue Jishu Chubanshe| pages=3–6 | location=Beijing | year=1994 | isbn=7-5046-1676-1 }}. * {{citation |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gjYWGIH9rZcC&printsec=frontcover |title=Reconstruction Designs of Lost Ancient Chinese Machinery |last=Yan |first=Hong-sen |series=''History of Mechanism and Machine Science'', No. 3 |publisher=Springer |location=Dordrecht |date=2007 |at=[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gjYWGIH9rZcC&pg=PA269 §8.1: "Lu Ban the Man"] }}. * {{citation |last=Yu |first=Xuecai |authormask=Yu Xuecai |author2=Li Chunfu |display-authors=1 |contribution=Gongshu Ban, Monograph in Research Library of Chinese Architectural Culture No. 22 |title=Huazhong Architecture Bimonthly |date=May 2004 |contribution-url=http://www.cotsa.com/cotsa/files/公输般.pdf }}. ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060926105515/http://www.techno.edu.ru:8001/images/pub_en_jour/2006/03/01/0000028428/hmm_3-22.pdf A Restoration of Lu-Ban's Wooden Horse Carriage] (PDF) *[http://ctext.org/mozi Mozi (Chinese text and Mei translation)] - [[Chinese Text Project]] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lu, Ban}} [[Category:500s BC births]] [[Category:444 BC deaths]] [[Category:5th-century BC Chinese people]] [[Category:Chinese gods]] [[Category:Chinese inventors]] [[Category:Deified Chinese people]] [[Category:Engineers from Shandong]] [[Category:Lu (state)]] [[Category:Chinese structural engineers]] [[Category:Water gods]] [[Category:Woodworkers]]

'''MeyGen''' (full name '''MeyGen tidal energy project''') is the worlds largest [[tidal power|tidal energy]] plant, which is currently in construction.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dickie|first1=Mure |title=Scotland unveils world’s largest tidal stream power project|url= https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:NLYheToLCeAJ:https://www.ft.com/content/d197308a-7826-11e6-97ae-647294649b28+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us |accessdate=9 December 2016|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=12 September 2016}}</ref> The project uses four 1.5 MW turbines with 16m rotor diameter turbines<!--style of [[wind turbine]]s--> submerged on the seabed.<ref name="guard">{{cite news|title=World's first large-scale tidal energy farm launches in Scotland|url= https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/sep/12/worlds-first-large-scale-tidal-energy-farm-launches-scotland |accessdate=9 December 2016|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=12 September 2016}}</ref> The project is owned and run by Tidal Power Scotland Limited and [[Scottish Enterprise]].
The high speed of currents in the area, reaching up to 5 metres per second (11 mph), made the chosen site in the [[Pentland Firth]] well suited to this type of energy generation.<ref name=Connor20130710>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/wave-goodbye-to-hope-of-tidal-energy-exports-scots-politicians-told-8698504.html | title=Wave goodbye to hope of tidal energy exports, Scots politicians told | first=Steve | last=Connor | date=10 July 2013 | newspaper=[[The Independent]]}}</ref>
In October 2010 the newly named "MeyGen" tidal project from the nearby [[Castle of Mey]] and "Gen" for generation was created by a consortium of [[Atlantis Resources]] Limited, [[Morgan Stanley]] and received operational lease from the [[Crown Estate]] to a 400 MW project for 25 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Major Scottish tidal project unveiled|url= https://www.newcivilengineer.com/news/energy/major-scottish-tidal-project-unveiled/8607525.article |accessdate=9 December 2016|agency=[[New Civil Engineer]]|date=28 October 2010}}</ref> Phase 1a began operations in April 2018<ref>{{cite news|title=Meygen Starts 25 year operations phase|url=http://www.4coffshore.com/windfarms/meygen-starts-25-years-operations-phase-nid7458.html}}</ref>. Phase 1b is undergoing construction and commissioning with a total of 8 1.5 MW turbines planned. Phase 1c, which will be 49 turbines, will begin construction and deployment in 2018 with the rest of the project aiming to be fully deployed by 2021.<ref name="guard"/>
In December 2016 it was announced that the first turbine had begun full power operations,<ref>{{cite web|title=Atlantis’ first MeyGen tidal turbine starts operating at full power|url= http://www.power-technology.com/news/newsatlantis-first-meygen-tidal-turbine-starts-operating-at-full-power-5690870 |website=Power Technology|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> and all four turbines were installed by February 2017. Atlantis plans for 400 MW.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.4coffshore.com/windfarms/atlantis-installs-fourth-and-final-meygen-phase-1a-turbine-nid5349.html |title=Atlantis installs fourth and final Meygen Phase 1A turbine|work=4c Offshore|date=20 February 2017|accessdate=26 February 2017}}</ref>
